body:
of course, adding sqlite_strict is simple and we can accept PRs for this which include tests and we will also backport to the 1.4 series.  also needs some docs added to sqlite/base.py.

the hard part of STRICT will be how badly all the datatypes behave.  however, we have a long way before we start getting complaints like that as current cPython distributions won't include this latest SQLite for a little while (you can of course build python with it, but that's less common).

Thanks!

+1 that there is no rush on this as most users might have an earlier version of `sqlite3`.
I for one have been using the [pre-compiled binaries](https://www.sqlite.org/download.html) a lot, but that might not be as common.

Do you have any ideas on how users would best be able to configure this?

the `<dialect>_<option>` on the `Table` declaration is the standard approach for all parameters like this, such as `mysql_engine='InnoDB'`.

Standard ways to automate this currently include events like [before_parent_attach](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/events.html?highlight=parent_attach#sqlalchemy.events.DDLEvents.before_parent_attach) but we don't have an example for this now, which would be suitable at https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/metadata.html#backend-specific-options which is right now very thin.

as for `MetaData` including parameters that are set on all tables by default, that would be a separate feature add (and also would be documented in that above section).

issue.title: Throw error when db is missing table schema

milestone.title: 2023 Winter
milestone.description: The main goal of our 2023 Q1 release is to get the ETL migrated into Dagster and have all of our useful output and analysis tables written directly into the database we distribute. See #2246 and #1973

repository.name: pudl
repository.description: The Public Utility Data Liberation Project provides analysis-ready energy system data to climate advocates, researchers, policymakers, and journalists.

issue.body:
@zaneselvans flagged in #2403 we aren't raising an error when an asset using the pudl_sqlite_io_manager does have a corresponding table schema defined in `pudl.metadata.resources`. This PR throws and error in this case and adds some additional SQLiteIOManager tests.

<!--

Making a PUDL Pull Request

Before making a PR you may want to check out our:

* contributing guidelines: https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/CONTRIBUTING.html
* code of conduct: https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/code_of_conduct.html
* development process: https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/index.html

## PR Process Overview

* PRs have to get an approving review before merging into their development branch.
* Most PRs should be made against the `dev` branch, unless they are part of some larger ongoing refactoring, in which case there will be a persistent development branch for that work.
* It is much easier to do timely code reviews on smaller chunks of code. We try to keep PRs under 500 lines of code.
* Draft PRs are a good way to get early feedback on designs or several incremental commits that will add up to larger changes. If you want a review of a draft PR, make sure you contact the reviewer directly or mention their username in the PR comment, so they get a notification.
* How quickly we can review a PR will depend on how large and complex it is, and how busy we are, but ideally we strive to get an initial review done within a week. If there are going to be delays, we should at least comment on the PR to let you know the situation.
* If you believe you've addressed a reviewer's comments, respond with a brief note and mark the comment resolved. If further discussion is requried respond and do not resolve the comment.
* Before a PR is merged all reviewer comments should be resolved. If a reviewer doesn't feel that their comment has been sufficiently addressed, they may unresolve a comment.
* Be careful not to accidentally "start a review" when responding to comments! If this does happen, don't forget to submit the review you've started so the other PR participatns can see your comments (they are invisible to others if marked "Pending").
* In the period after an initial review when there is significant back-and-forth with the reviewer deciding what changes should actually be made, there should probably be daily interaction. If significant changes are required, it's usually best to request another review after those changes have been made.

Feel free to delete the commented-out parts of the template before submitting the PR.

-->

# PR Overview

<!--

Include a short narrative summary of what's going on in the PR. This can be a bulleted list. You might want to include:

* What are you changing and why?
* Are there any known unsolved problems remaining in the PR?
* Is there anything that you want a reivewer to pay particular attention to?
* What kind of feedback are you looking for on the PR?

-->

# PR Checklist

- [ ] Merge the most recent version of the branch you are merging into (probably `dev`).
- [ ] All CI checks are passing. [Run tests locally to debug failures](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/testing.html#running-tests-with-tox)
- [ ] Make sure you've included good docstrings.
- [ ] For major data coverage & analysis changes, [run data validation tests](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/testing.html#data-validation)
- [ ] Include unit tests for new functions and classes.
- [ ] Defensive data quality/sanity checks in analyses & data processing functions.
- [ ] Update the [release notes](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/release_notes.html) and reference reference the PR and related issues.
- [ ] Do your own explanatory review of the PR to help the reviewer understand what's going on and identify issues preemptively.

issue.title: Create workaround to handle unexpected SQLite Integer Primary Key behavior

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Things that are just plain broken.

repository.name: pudl
repository.description: The Public Utility Data Liberation Project provides analysis-ready energy system data to climate advocates, researchers, policymakers, and journalists.

issue.body:
## Background
SQLite[ uses an autoincrement function ](https://www.sqlite.org/autoinc.html) to fill in missing values when a table has a non composite integer primary key. Luckily we only have a few tables that fall into this category and missing values are handled during the transformation steps. See this [PR convo](https://github.com/catalyst-cooperative/pudl/pull/2410/files#r1140471930) for additional context.

> On an [INSERT](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_insert.html), if the ROWID or INTEGER PRIMARY KEY column is not explicitly given a value, then it will be filled automatically with an unused integer, usually one more than the largest ROWID currently in use. This is true regardless of whether or not the AUTOINCREMENT keyword is used.

To avoid this behavior, SQLite recommends using [`WITHOUT ROWID` phrase](https://www.sqlite.org/withoutrowid.html):

> The special behaviors associated "[INTEGER PRIMARY KEY](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html#rowid)" do not apply on WITHOUT ROWID tables. In an ordinary table, "INTEGER PRIMARY KEY" means that the column is an alias for the rowid. But since there is no rowid in a WITHOUT ROWID table, that special meaning no longer applies. An "INTEGER PRIMARY KEY" column in a WITHOUT ROWID table works like an "INT PRIMARY KEY" column in an ordinary table: It is a PRIMARY KEY that has integer [affinity](https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity).

[SQLite has a parameter](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/dialects/sqlite.html#sqlite-specific-table-options) for controlling this behavior... great!

Not great. As the quote above says, an Integer Primary Key in a table using the WITHOUT ROWID becomes a INT PRIMARY KEY that has *integer affinity*.[ From what I can tell sqlite won't throw an error if a string that can't be cast to int is loaded to the db.](https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity) I was able to load `"abc"` value into an "INTEGER PRIMARY KEY" column using WITHOUT ROWID.

SQLite offers a [STRICT phrase](https://www.sqlite.org/stricttables.html) that might restrict the type affinity rules but[ sqlalchemy doesn't support it yet.](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/7398)

## Solutions
- Add some logic to the SQLiteIOManager that does some checks on primary keys in pandas.
- Start using [dagster-pandera](https://docs.dagster.io/integrations/pandera) to do some integrity constraints on dataframes before they are loaded to the db.
- Research tools that can apply integrity constraints to any type of database so we don't have do integrity check in pandas or create custom test suites for different backends. Maybe [Great Expectations](https://docs.greatexpectations.io/docs/)?

body:
In case someone is looking for this too, and stumbles on this issue via search, like I did:

Here's a very ugly hack that gets it done (for me at least).

```python
import re

from sqlalchemy import Engine, event, Table, MetaData, Connection, text
from sqlalchemy.orm import DeclarativeBase
from sqlalchemy.schema import CreateTable


class MyBase(DeclarativeBase):
    pass


@event.listens_for(MyBase.metadata, "before_create")
def sqlite_default_strict_tables(target: MetaData, connection: Connection, **kw):
    """
    This enables strict tables by default, which is necessary to enforce column type constraints on SQLite.
    Cf. `SQLite docs <https://www.sqlite.org/stricttables.html>`
    """
    # you might have to adjust these, depending on your data types
    replacement_map = {
        r"VARCHAR(\(\d+\))?": "TEXT",
        r"DATETIME": "TEXT",
        r"DATE": "TEXT",
        r"JSON": "TEXT",
    }

    for table in target.sorted_tables:
        def redefine(target: Table, connection: Connection, **kwargs):
            if connection.engine.echo:
                print("# DROP non-strict table")
            target.drop(connection)

            statement_str = str(CreateTable(target).compile(connection)).rstrip() + " STRICT"
            for old, new in replacement_map.items():
                statement_str = re.sub(old, new, statement_str)
            statement = text(statement_str)
            connection.execute(statement)

        event.listen(table, "after_create", redefine)
```

Honestly, I don't think this is such a good idea, but if you need it, you're free to shoot your own foot with this.

**EDIT: This answer is obsolete due to [a better workaround](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/7398#issuecomment-1772821099) existing.**

Here's my solution to the problem. It's based on @FynnFreyer's solution, but it should in theory be more robust (since we don't recompute the sql statement for creating the table, and I check for a few more potential errors). And it works for non-ORM use cases.

Caveats (some of which also applies to @FynnFreyer's solution):
* WILL delete your indexes.
* For types you use that aren't [supported by SQLite strict tables](https://www.sqlite.org/stricttables.html), you need to [override their compilation](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/custom_types.html#overriding-type-compilation) so they get compiled into a supported SQLite type.
* Requires that you already have a schema of all the tables you want to make strict.
* Untested with ORM, but replacing the redefine method in @FynnFreyer's solution with my `recreate_table_as_strict` should work.
* Untested with non-default SQLite databases (e.g. a table named `my_db.my_table`).
* Use for whatever you want but at your own risk.

```python
import re
from typing import Any

from sqlalchemy import (
    Connection,
    MetaData,
    Table,
    column,
    event,
    literal_column,
    select,
    text,
)
from sqlalchemy.dialects.sqlite import TEXT


def recreate_table_as_strict(target: Table, connection: Connection, **kwargs: Any):
    assert connection.dialect.name == "sqlite", "Only sqlite3 tables can be strict."

    table_sql_result = connection.execute(
        select(literal_column("sql", TEXT))
        .select_from(text("sqlite_schema"))
        .where(column("type") == "table")
        .where(column("name") == target.name)
    )
    table_sql = table_sql_result.fetchone()[0]  # type: ignore
    assert isinstance(table_sql, str)

    table_sql = table_sql.rstrip(" \n\t;")
    assert not table_sql.endswith("STRICT")
    table_sql = table_sql + " STRICT"

    if connection.engine.echo:
        print("# DROP non-strict table")
    target.drop(connection)
    if connection.engine.echo:
        print("# re-CREATE table as STRICT")
    connection.execute(text(table_sql))


def make_table_strict(target: Table):
    """
    Edits an existing table schema to be created as a STRICT table.
    See https://www.sqlite.org/stricttables.html
    """
    event.listen(target, "after_create", recreate_table_as_strict)


def make_all_tables_strict(metadata: MetaData):
    """
    Edits an existing schema so all of its tables are created as STRICT tables.
    See https://www.sqlite.org/stricttables.html
    """
    for table in metadata.tables.values():
        make_table_strict(table)

make_all_tables_strict(put_your_metadata_here)
```

> the `<dialect>_<option>` on the `Table` declaration is the standard approach for all parameters like this, such as `mysql_engine='InnoDB'`.

having a more open ended feature similar to `prefixes` would be an option here? like `suffixes` to put stuff after the table definition. this could also be leverages for other open ended features, similar to what prefixes does?

> Here's my solution to the problem. It's based on @FynnFreyer's solution, but it should in theory be more robust (since we don't recompute the sql statement for creating the table, and I check for a few more potential errors). And it works for non-ORM use cases.


a pull request to add this keyword to SQLAlchemy would be less code and effort than these workarounds

> > Here's my solution to the problem. It's based on @FynnFreyer's solution, but it should in theory be more robust (since we don't recompute the sql statement for creating the table, and I check for a few more potential errors). And it works for non-ORM use cases.
> 
> a pull request to add this keyword to SQLAlchemy would be less code and effort than these workarounds

I just found out about the [Overriding Type Compilation](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/custom_types.html#overriding-type-compilation) functionality, which simplifies the most error-prone part of the workaround. I've edited my answer accordingly.

@theemathas looks cool, I'll test this for ORM if I get around to it.

@zzzeek I'm sure you're right, but I wouldn't even know where to start, so I use an ugly hack instead. If you could point us into the right direction, I'd consider doing it the right way
